Problem:
Consider a complex function in the form of \\( z(t) = e^{iAt}x \\) where x is a constant complex vector and A is a constant real matrix. We assess the behavior of the function after applying a Laplace transform, defined as \\( \\mathcal{L}(z(t)) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st}z(t) dt \\).

If, at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), an external vector function \\( y = e^{-Bt}w \\) (where B is a constant matrix and w a constant vector) is added, will the resulting transform \\( Z(s) \\) for s > 0 purely depend on A and ignore the effects of B?
Explanation: Applying \\( y = e^{-Bt}w \\) introduces an additional term to z(t), which affects the overall Laplace transform. The resulting transform function \\( Z(s) \\) will depend both on A and B due to the additive nature of the functions in the time domain affecting the frequency domain representation.
